content.body: I put this in TC39 delegates, but I think it might be more appropriate here: is the expectation that ShadowRealms should not share module graphs. That is to say, import { x } from "y", that x should have nothing in common from the same x imported from y in a parent realm -- but is the module resolution/caching/etc. also "reset" (or is that piece host dependent -- or does that potentially introduce a "side channel" for the ShadowRealm to determine if a module has been imported in the parent if it loads quickly)?
if the cache is shared, then it wouldn't tell them about the parent, because it could have been loaded in a different shadowrealm
They are two separate modules, similarly to what would happen if you load `"y"` in two different workers
content.formatted_body: They are two separate modules, similarly to what would happen if you load "y" in two different workers

content.body: I'm not 100% sure that the proposal mandates that, but the HTML side of the modules algorithms does
Specifically, the "module key" in ECMA-262 is (importer, specifier), and those two "y"s have different importers
content.formatted_body: Specifically, the "module key" in ECMA-262 is (importer, specifier), and those two "y"s have different importers

content.body: Oh actually, re-reading: yes, that introduces a timing side channel
content.formatted_body: Oh actually, re-reading: yes, that introduces a timing side channel

content.body: The JS value is separate, but the module source might have been pre-cached
To make shadowrealms safe however, you have to disable timers regardless of this
is "importer" synonymous with "loader", or is an importer different than a loader (by loader I mean (https://whatwg.github.io/loader/), or JSModuleLoader in JavaScriptCore
